#Text=Operate Multiple Computers With One Keyboard and Monitor
#Text=Here 's a convenient way to operate two ( or more ) computers from one location without the need for duplicating a keyboard , mouse and monitor .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Determine which method works best for you .
#Text=Hardware and software based solutions are available .
#Text=Read on to help figure out which is best for your personal situation .
#Text=A software based solution will require that each computer under control has a network connection .
#Text=The network can be a LAN if it will be controlled locally only , or an internet connection if it will need to be controlled from any computer in the world with an internet connection .
#Text=Obtain software and service for your computers .
#Text=One such provider is LogMeIn .

#Text=They have several levels of service ranging from free for " simple remote control " ( LogMeInFree ) to the more robust " full service " offerings ( such as LogMeInPro ) but has a monthly fee of about US$ 20 per computer .

column1: #Text=The LogMeIn service in general works very well , but like any network based solution , is best when connected by high speed LAN or broadband internet between the computers .
#Text=Select the service level that best meets your needs , create an account and download / install the software .
#Text=A second software based option is the open source solution called " synergy "
#Text=this works across operating systems , when simply trying to control several computers locally with one keyboard and mouse , a " soft " KVM switch if you will .
#Text=A hardware based solution can be achieved with a " KVM Switch "

column1: #Text=KVM is an acronym for " Keyboard , Video , Mouse " .

column1: #Text=These devices typically have connections for multiple Video inputs from the computers and a single output to connect to a monitor .
#Text=There are also multiple PS/2 Mouse and Keyboard outputs to connect to the computers and two inputs for connecting both a keyboard and a mouse .
#Text=Newer KVM switches have transitioned from PS/2 and round Keyboard connectors to the popular USB ports instead .
#Text=Be sure to obtain a KVM that supports the style Keyboard and Mouse connectors the computer uses or obtain adapters .

#Text=Due to limitations on the length of cable that KVM ( and USB for that matter ) signals can travel , all the computers will probably have to be located fairly close ( within 10 feet or so of the KVM hardware ) unless some other repeater or extender hardware is employed .
#Text=Purchase any additional cables needed to complete connections between the KVM and the computers and I/O devices .
#Text=Select the product that has computer and operating system(s) support for your setup .
#Text=Many KVM 's install device drivers and use a small program to switch between computers .
#Text=This means if multiple OS 's are involved , drivers will be required for each in order to work properly .
#Text=Install the KVM and software as specified in the manufacturer 's instructions .
#Text=Video
